title: fix: enhance human PR detection to reduce false positives
description:
## Summary

This PR addresses issue #14 by enhancing the LLM evaluator to better detect human-made PRs and reduce false positives. The changes specifically handle cases like PR #12, which was incorrectly flagged as AI-generated when it was actually a human-made fix to CI/CD workflows.

## Changes

### Features
- **PR Context Analysis**: Now evaluates PR title, description, and commit messages to identify human patterns
- **Smarter AI Detection**: Requires majority of files to be AI-generated with high confidence (>75%) before flagging as AI
- **CI/CD File Recognition**: Special handling for workflow files where humans often make targeted fixes

### Improvements
- **Code Organization**: Refactored evaluator with extracted constants and focused methods for better maintainability
- **Reduced False Positives**: Default to human authorship for ambiguous cases, only flag as AI with strong evidence
- **Context-Aware Evaluation**: Recognizes human patterns like terse fix titles, missing descriptions, and formatting-only changes in CI files

### Breaking Changes
None - the public API remains unchanged

### Bug Fixes
- Fixed incorrect AI detection for minimal PRs with no description and targeted CI/CD fixes
- Maintained strong AI signal detection that cannot be overridden by PR context

Fixes #14

commitMessages:
fix: enhance human PR detection to reduce false positives

- Add PR context analysis (title, description, commit messages) to evaluation
- Require majority of files to be AI-generated with high confidence (>75%)
- Recognize human patterns: terse fix titles, no description, CI/CD file changes
- Maintain strong AI signal detection that cannot be overridden
- Refactor code for better organization with extracted constants and focused methods

This specifically addresses PR #12 which was incorrectly flagged as AI-generated
when it was a human-made fix to CI/CD workflows.

Fixes #14

fix: update integration test expectation for stricter AI detection

The test "should evaluate a complete PR with multiple file types" was expecting
human-like result when there's a debug.js file mixed with AI-generated files.
With our new stricter logic that reduces false positives, having 2 AI files
with strong signals vs 1 human file correctly results in overall AI detection.

Updated test comment and expectation to match the new behavior where strong
AI signals in majority of files override individual human-like files.
